transcript.clinician: Hello, Alison, please come and have a seat. Hi, I'm one of the GPs at this clinic. What would you like me to call you?
transcript.patient: Alison would be fine.

transcript.clinician: Okay, so what's brought you here today, Alison?
transcript.patient: Sisters, lady. I'm just a bit fuddled up, really. My sister said I should come.

transcript.clinician: Right, okay. Has this been going on for some time?
transcript.patient: A few months.

transcript.clinician: Do you want to tell me a bit more about what's been going on?
transcript.patient: I just... things seem to be piling up, I just don't seem to be keeping with things right at home.

transcript.clinician: Okay. The kids and things, right?
transcript.patient: Okay.

transcript.clinician: Would it be okay, Alison, for me to ask you a few more detailed questions about how you've been feeling?
transcript.patient: Okay.

transcript.clinician: Well, if we start with asking a bit about your mood, how have you been feeling in yourself?
transcript.patient: A bit fed up. At 4 in the morning, everything just seems very black. It's just like swimming and tree cooling in. And I just don't... I think by tea time, by the time the kids get home, I've been able to have a fairly decent conversation with them.

transcript.clinician: But, and can I just check, Alison, when you say things feel very black, do you mean you feel very...?
transcript.patient: Miserable.

transcript.clinician: Miserable, okay. And what about sort of feeling tearful? Has that been happening?
transcript.patient: I dropped my sugar the other day and I just burst into tears.

transcript.clinician: So is it the slightest thing that would make you feel tearful? Things that perhaps wouldn't ordinarily bother you?
transcript.patient: Yeah, my sister's noticed as well.

transcript.clinician: Right, okay. So you've been feeling very low and with episodes of tearfulness. What about other things? What about your energy levels? Are you managing to keep up with things?
transcript.patient: I used to do a lot with the kids. I used to playing with them, but now I just spend the day on the sofa, really, have to go to work.

transcript.clinician: And just remind me, what is it you do for a living? So how have you been managing at work?
transcript.patient: I'm not been going in as much because I just feel so exhausted. But I mean, we're just not... The supermarket's been taken over and they've cut the wages, and problems with the bills, it's like catalogues again, just write me letters. You know, the kids, they want all these new games and stuff. It's just, you know.

transcript.clinician: Things are really difficult all round. With all this going on, how are you sleeping, Alison?
transcript.patient: It takes me a year to go to sleep. I used to read a book, and drop off. But now I just spend my time looking at the clock, it goes round.

transcript.clinician: So from actually getting off to bed and getting off to sleep, how long is that taking?
transcript.patient: A couple of hours, probably.

transcript.clinician: Once you're actually asleep, are you waking up much during the night?
transcript.patient: I wake up about... last night, I think it was about 4 o'clock I caught.

transcript.clinician: And can you get back to sleep from that time?
transcript.patient: No.

transcript.clinician: And then when you're actually getting out of bed in the morning, are you still feeling tired at that point?
transcript.patient: Exhausted. I feel like my brain's not being switched off and just exhausted... to the legs day.

transcript.clinician: Okay. What about eating? What's your appetite been like while you've been feeling like this?
transcript.patient: I used to have quite a weight problem, but the last couple of months that's just a bit looser, just... know how. No, no, the kids come in from school and they make their own stuff, you know, just don't bother, really.

transcript.clinician: Okay, so your appetite's gone down as well. What about things like concentrating and your memory, both when, I don't know, watching TV at home or out when you're out doing your job?
transcript.patient: Well, it... might be pretty useless with the kids. So I forgot the swimming money last week, PE kit and parents' evening, even, start one job and... like I'm not explaining myself very well, it's like the television, I used to like watching the soaps, EastEnders or something, and 10 minutes later just... you know, I'm thinking of something else.

transcript.clinician: Okay. And what about things, Alison, that you used to enjoy? Are there things in life that you still enjoy at the moment?
transcript.patient: Nothing really. As I say, a bit useless with the kids, used to enjoy going out. I used to go out with my friends for pictures and things. But of course, now... just can't be bothered. You don't feel like it as well. What's the point, really? You know?

transcript.clinician: And I was going to ask, how old are your children now?
transcript.patient: I had a bit late, didn't I? It took a long, long time for me to have them. I've got a girl and a boy, one's 11, one's 9.

transcript.clinician: And looking after children takes a lot of time and energy. How are you managing to keep up with that, feeling as low as you do?
transcript.patient: Well, they're a bit self-sufficient, really. The kids do, they're from school, get their own tea, I should be doing more for them really, but now I'm just a bit useless at that at the moment.

transcript.clinician: And what about looking after yourself?
transcript.patient: Well, you can see I'm just a mess. Dave used to say, that's my boyfriend, I used to, you know, not have much money, but I'd take a bit of pride in what I was doing, you know, and my hair and stuff. Back home, can't be bothered with that. Now's no point, really.

transcript.clinician: And you mentioned Dave, that's your current partner. How long have you and Dave been together?
transcript.patient: About a year, but...

transcript.clinician: And how are things, because often when people feel really down, it has a real impact on everything, including their relationships. How are things between you and Dave at the moment?
transcript.patient: Well, he's not ringing as much, there used to be texts, but he's going, you know, he's getting fed up with me not wanting to go out

transcript.clinician: It's a slightly embarrassing thing to ask about, but I guess it's important. Often when people are really feeling very low, it affects everything in their relationship, including things like the sex life. Have you noticed any changes there for you?
transcript.patient: He's always trying to pressure me a little bit. I'm really not into that at the moment.

transcript.clinician: Just don't feel like that at the moment.
transcript.patient: Yeah

transcript.clinician: Okay. So can I just recap, Alison, and check I've got this right? For the last few months, you've been feeling really down, no energy, problems with your sleeping and eating, problems with concentrating, not really enjoying things and actually struggling a bit with the kids and perhaps some difficulties in your relationship with Dave. Have I got that right?
transcript.patient: Yeah

transcript.clinician: Can I ask, Alison, in the past, have there ever been episodes when you felt like this?
transcript.patient: When my husband left. I was always crying then, for no particular reason. I haven't told anybody this before, but I took some tablets.

transcript.clinician: So how long ago were we talking about this? A few years ago?
transcript.patient: About four years. About four years ago.

transcript.clinician: Okay, so you took some tablets. Can you tell me, is it all right? Tell me a little bit more about that.
transcript.patient: What it's like? Kids are in bed. And you're on your own. And had a few glasses of wine, and just took these tablets.

transcript.clinician: Okay. Do you remember what you actually took at the time, what sort of tablets they were?
transcript.patient: They just did the bathroom cabinet and... paracetamol

transcript.clinician: Okay, so you took some paracetamol. Can you remember sort of roughly how many you took?
transcript.patient: About almost two strips, about 12.

transcript.clinician: Right, okay. And you'd had a couple of glasses of wine. Did you take anything else, any other tablets with it? And was this something, Alison, that you'd thought about for a while, or was it something that was quite a sort of spur of the moment decision that evening?
transcript.patient: There are so many crying a lot, but I just... but you know, it's a... of a burden to everybody really.

transcript.clinician: And was there any other things you did around the time? Sometimes when people take time, because they leave a note or do other kind of final acts, get their affairs in order, did you do any of those things?
transcript.patient: Just took the tablets and go to sleep.

transcript.clinician: Okay? So did you have any thoughts about what taking the tablets would do? Did you...?
transcript.patient: I just thought I'd go to sleep and not wake up. But I woke up a couple of hours later and I was really sick everywhere. God.

transcript.clinician: So, so you actually, if I wanted to check, I get this right? Because at this point, you actually thought they would kill you? At the time.
transcript.patient: I just did one call. I just say I'm just a useless, just a useless mom now. And I was there.

transcript.clinician: Okay. So you took the tablets, you were very sick in the night. Did you seek any medical help at the time?
transcript.patient: No, no.

transcript.clinician: Okay. And then you were okay the following day?
transcript.patient: Yeah, just felt a bit of a twit, really.

transcript.clinician: Did you feel pleased that you were still alive?
transcript.patient: Yeah, I think, you know, I realized it would just be silly.

transcript.clinician: So that was a few years ago. So if we just come back to how you're feeling at the moment, you've talked about feeling very low. Have there been times currently when you've thought about either taking an overdose or doing something else to harm yourself in any way?
transcript.patient: You know what, no. When you're watching the clock and you know you're on your own, the kids are in bed, it just... everything's so hard. And yeah, but you know, it just feels easy, you know?

transcript.clinician: And has that just been something you've thought about? Have you actually made any plans, got any tablets in or done anything else?
transcript.patient: No.

transcript.clinician: And I guess it's a difficult question to ask, but one we would ask everybody in your situation. Have things ever been so bad, you've got so low that you've not only thought about harming yourself or perhaps killing yourself, but also wondered whether the best thing might be to take the children with you?
transcript.patient: My kids, they look like kids. no.

transcript.clinician: Okay. And what about sort of the other side of that, things, positive things, sort of things to look for, things that you feel good about?
transcript.patient: Not... kids sometimes, you know? They do things that make you think, you know, I don't... what's good about life and things, but...

transcript.clinician: And are there other things that help then? I'm thinking about people who can be supportive.
transcript.patient: My sister, as I say, she said to get down here and she's always there. She comes down, rings, got a couple of friends, they're quite good, but on day one is in the mood, of course, but I don't think he's going to be around for much longer.

transcript.clinician: Do you think or do you feel able to keep yourself safe at the moment from hurting yourself?
transcript.patient: So yeah. And I know I can come here now, and you've been very good today.

transcript.clinician: Do you think if that was to change so that you didn't feel you're able to keep yourself safe, you'd be able to let anybody know?
transcript.patient: All I know what happened last time, that was nothing. No, no, no, no, was silly then. So now I'd come here.

transcript.clinician: Okay, so, well, thanks for going through all that. I can appreciate it must be very painful. It does sound to me like you are suffering from symptoms that strongly suggest that you're actually depressed at the moment. Now, I'm not sure how much you know about depression.
transcript.patient: Not much really

transcript.clinician: Well, I guess just briefly, depression can cause a number of problems for people. Traditionally, we think about people feeling very low and very miserable and often thinking about hurting themselves, but it can also affect all other areas of life in terms of problems of eating and sleeping. And the other problems you've noticed is that concentration and perhaps not really managing as well as normal. I guess the positive side is that you've done something about it and you've come to talk to me about it today. And I think there are almost certainly a range of things we can put in place to help you and treatments that are available. So I guess what I'm thinking was it might be worth just spending a few minutes just thinking about some of those options for you so that we can start to improve things for you. Would that be all right with you?
transcript.patient: I need to do this. Yes, sounds sensible. Yeah.

clinical_note:
**Subjective:**  
Alison, a woman in her late 30s to early 40s, presents today at the urging of her sister due to feeling "fuddled up" and low for the past few months. She describes persistent low mood, particularly severe in the early morning hours, with feelings of misery and tearfulness triggered by minor events. Alison reports significant anhedonia, stating she no longer enjoys activities she previously liked, such as spending time with her children or going out with friends. She feels exhausted, spends most days on the sofa, and has been missing work at the supermarket due to low energy and motivation. She reports financial stressors and relationship difficulties with her partner, Dave, who has become more distant. Alison describes poor sleep initiation (taking hours to fall asleep), frequent early morning awakening (around 4 am), and inability to return to sleep, resulting in persistent fatigue. Appetite has decreased, and she has lost weight. She reports poor concentration and memory, forgetting tasks related to her children and work, and difficulty following television programs. Alison feels she is not caring for herself or her children as she would like, expressing guilt and worthlessness. She denies current suicidal ideation or plans but has a history of a paracetamol overdose four years ago during a previous depressive episode, which she describes as impulsive and not premeditated. She has supportive relationships with her sister and some friends, and states she feels able to keep herself safe at present.

**Objective:**  
- Appearance: Disheveled, low affect, poor self-care as per self-report.
- Speech: Slow, monotone, coherent.
- Mood: Subjectively low, congruent affect.
- Thought process: Logical, though preoccupied with feelings of worthlessness and guilt.
- No evidence of psychosis or current suicidal intent.
- Insight: Good; recognizes symptoms and is seeking help.
- Social: Two children (ages 9 and 11), lives with them, has a partner (relationship strained), supportive sister.
- Function: Marked impairment in occupational, social, and parental roles.
- No reported substance misuse (apart from occasional alcohol in the past).
- No acute medical issues reported.

**Assessment:**  
Alison is experiencing a moderate to severe depressive episode, characterized by persistent low mood, anhedonia, sleep and appetite disturbance, low energy, poor concentration, feelings of worthlessness, and significant functional impairment. There is a past history of a suicide attempt (paracetamol overdose) during a previous episode of depression, but no current suicidal ideation or intent. She has some protective factors, including her children, sister, and willingness to seek help. There are significant psychosocial stressors, including financial difficulties and relationship strain. No evidence of psychosis or mania.

**Plan:**  
1. **Pharmacological:** Initiate Sertraline 50 mg once daily in the morning. Discussed potential side effects (e.g., GI upset, sleep disturbance, increased anxiety initially) and the need for several weeks before full effect.
2. **Psychosocial:** Encouraged Alison to maintain contact with her sister and supportive friends. Advised on the importance of routine and self-care, even in small steps.
3. **Safety:** Alison denies current suicidal ideation or intent and has a safety plan in place (will contact clinic or sister if thoughts worsen). Provided crisis contact information.
4. **Follow-up:** Review in 2 weeks to assess response to medication, side effects, and risk. Sooner review if symptoms worsen or suicidal thoughts emerge.
5. **Further support:** Discussed referral to counseling or psychological therapies (e.g., CBT) and provided information on local services.
6. **Work:** Advised to consider discussing her situation with her employer and to seek support if needed.
7. **Education:** Provided psychoeducation about depression, its symptoms, and the expected course of treatment.

Alison was receptive to the plan and agreed to start medication and attend follow-up. She understands the importance of seeking help if her safety becomes a concern.

data_insights: PHQ-4 and PSS-4 scores remain stable, despite fluctuating sleep and activity patterns.
High stress and low positive affect persist, despite increased physical activity and stable sleep patterns.
Positive affect remains low, even as physical activity and steps increase.
Sleep duration and quality fluctuate, but emotional state scores remain stable.
Despite high time at home, no increase in digital or phone-based social contact.
Unique WiFi and Bluetooth device counts remain low, indicating little change in social or environmental context.
Despite increased physical activity, time in green and exercise spaces remains at zero.
Routine regularity and time at home are high, but social contact remains minimal.
Digital engagement is high, but social interaction via calls remains low.
PHQ-4 depression scores dropped to zero, but anxiety scores remain stable at three.
Routine regularity and time at home remain high, with minimal variation in significant places visited.
Screen unlock episodes increased, but average unlock duration at home decreased, indicating fragmented digital engagement.
Total steps and physical activity increased after a period of low movement and high sedentary episodes.
No time spent in study or exercise spaces, consistent across all days.
Radius of travel frequently at zero, with rare brief increases, suggesting limited mobility.
Sleep patterns show high variability in bed and wake times, with frequent sleep episodes.
Awake duration during sleep periods increased, with more frequent awakenings at night.
Positive affect scores remain low and stable, with little improvement over time.
Negative affect scores decreased but remain above minimum, indicating persistent negative mood.
Missed call counts are consistently low, with minimal incoming or outgoing calls, suggesting limited social contact.
Routine regularity decreased slightly, but overall daily structure remains stable.
Maximum screen unlock duration at home decreased, while number of unlocks increased, suggesting shorter, more frequent device use.
Total sleep duration fluctuated, with periods of both very short and longer sleep.
Sedentary episodes increased as physical activity rose, possibly reflecting irregular activity patterns.
Outgoing call count increased slightly, but overall call activity remains low.
Total screen unlock duration at home decreased, despite stable or increased unlock episodes.
Number of significant places visited remains low, with only brief increases.
Maximum screen unlock duration increased sharply on some days, despite overall shorter average unlocks.
Sleep fragmentation increased, with more frequent and longer awake episodes during the night.
Despite increased steps, sedentary episodes also rise, indicating possible bursts of activity.
No evidence of medication or treatment changes in available data.

transcript.clinician: Hello Alison, it’s good to see you again. How are you feeling today since our last appointment?
transcript.patient: Hi. I’m... okay, I guess? Just a bit tired, really.

transcript.clinician: I remember last time you mentioned your sleep hasn’t been great. Has there been any change with your sleeping patterns lately?
transcript.patient: It’s mostly the same. Some nights I get a few hours, other times I’m up all night, just staring at the phone or ceiling. I still feel tired all the time.

transcript.clinician: That sounds really tough. Have you noticed if anything makes your sleep a bit better or worse?
transcript.patient: If I try to walk more or when I’m really exhausted from work, I might nod off quicker. But sometimes even then, I wake up and can’t go back.

transcript.clinician: How about your appetite these days, Alison? Last time you said you weren’t eating much—has that improved at all?
transcript.patient: Not really. Most days I just skip lunch. Sometimes the kids make their own dinner and I just pick at what’s left, if anything.

transcript.clinician: Have you noticed any changes in your weight, or have people commented?
transcript.patient: My clothes feel a bit looser. My sister noticed I’ve lost a bit. But I don’t really check anymore.

transcript.clinician: You were continuing your Sertraline medication, is that right? Are you still taking it regularly?
transcript.patient: Yeah, I take it in the morning like supposed to. Haven’t missed a dose.

transcript.clinician: That’s good that you’re able to keep up with that, even with everything going on. Have you noticed any side effects or problems with the medication?
transcript.patient: No, not really. I don’t get any side effects or anything.

transcript.clinician: We also spoke before about how things have been feeling at home, especially with the kids. How has that been lately?
transcript.patient: It’s hard, honestly. They still pretty much look after themselves after school. I feel guilty... I know I should be doing more for them, but I just can’t.

transcript.clinician: It’s understandable to feel that way, especially when you’re dealing with depression and exhaustion. Have the kids said anything about it to you?
transcript.patient: Not really. My daughter helps her brother, makes sandwiches for them both. Sometimes she asks why I’m so tired. I just say work is hard.

transcript.clinician: And your relationship with Dave—how are things going there since we last spoke?
transcript.patient: Still a bit distant, I guess. We don’t really go out anymore. He calls less. Sometimes he seems frustrated. I know it’s because I’m not up for things, just not myself.

transcript.clinician: Have the two of you talked about how you’re feeling, or how it’s affecting the relationship?
transcript.patient: Not properly. He tries, but I just shut down a lot. He says I need to let him in, but I don’t know how.

transcript.clinician: It can be really difficult to open up when you’re feeling low. Would you feel comfortable if we talked about ways you might be able to share a little more with him?
transcript.patient: Maybe. It’s just, I feel like he doesn’t get it, and I don’t want to be a burden to him.

transcript.clinician: Those feelings are very common. Many people feel like they’re burdening loved ones, but often loved ones do want to help. Would you be open to exploring this further together—maybe what you might say, or how to start that conversation?
transcript.patient: Yeah, I think so. I just don’t know where to start, really.

transcript.clinician: That’s okay. We can talk about some simple ways to begin. Even just sharing that you’re struggling and that it’s hard to talk about can be a first step. Would you be willing to try saying that to Dave?
transcript.patient: I could try. I’m scared he’ll just get more frustrated though.

transcript.clinician: It's possible, but it could also help him understand what you’re going through. Maybe you could write down how you’re feeling before you say it, just to get your thoughts straight. Would that help?
transcript.patient: Maybe. I used to write in a diary sometimes. Haven’t done that in ages.

transcript.clinician: That’s a great idea—maybe picking that up again could be helpful, just for you too. It could help get some thoughts out of your head. Would you like to try starting that again over the next week?
transcript.patient: I could. I’ll try.

transcript.clinician: You mentioned your sister’s been supportive—has that continued? Are you able to see or talk with her often?
transcript.patient: Yeah, she drops by some days after work, or calls. She’s good to me, nags a bit, but she means well.

transcript.clinician: Having supportive people like her is so important. How do you feel after talking to her or seeing her?
transcript.patient: Usually a little better. Sometimes she makes me laugh. Sometimes I just feel guilty for being a mess.

transcript.clinician: It’s okay to feel that way, Alison, but remember you’re doing your best right now. Have you been able to see or talk with any other friends lately?
transcript.patient: Not really. I just don’t reach out. I feel like I’ve let most people drift away. Don’t want them to see me like this.

transcript.clinician: I understand. Social connection can help, even if it’s just a short message. Would you feel comfortable sending a text or message to a friend this week, just to say hello?
transcript.patient: I can try. Might just text my old work mate, see how she’s doing.

transcript.clinician: That sounds like a good plan. Sometimes a small step can make a difference. How about work—how have things been there?
transcript.patient: It’s been... unstable. They keep changing shifts, cutting hours. I’ve been missing days. Whole thing makes me anxious, but I need the job for the money.

transcript.clinician: That sounds incredibly stressful. Do you feel supported by anyone at work, or is there someone you can talk to about your schedule or workload?
transcript.patient: Not really. The new manager just cares about numbers. The other ladies I work with try, but everyone’s just worried about keeping their jobs.

transcript.clinician: It’s a difficult situation. Are you able to take breaks when you need them at work?
transcript.patient: Sort of. Sometimes I just go to the bathroom for a few minutes to breathe. But I don’t like leaving the floor—feels like someone will get mad.

transcript.clinician: You’re doing what you can. Let’s think together about managing the stress. Are there things, even very small, that help you calm down during your day?
transcript.patient: If I can step outside for a minute, get some air, it helps. Or just take a deep breath in the back room.

transcript.clinician: That’s good—you’ve found some coping skills already. Are you finding time at all to go outside or into any green spaces for yourself, even just a few minutes?
transcript.patient: No, not really. I usually just go from the flat to the bus or work and back. Don’t really go to parks or anything. Too tired.

transcript.clinician: Even a few minutes outside can sometimes help lift your mood a little. Would you be willing to try stepping outside for a short walk, maybe just down your street, once this week?
transcript.patient: I guess. If it’s not raining, maybe after I drop the kids at school.

transcript.clinician: That’s a good plan. Even five or ten minutes can sometimes help. We saw last time you’d increased your steps a bit—do you feel any difference when you’re a little more active?
transcript.patient: Maybe. I don’t notice much, but I guess I feel less anxious if I move instead of sit all day.

transcript.clinician: That’s a really positive thing to notice. It doesn’t have to be a lot—just a little extra movement can sometimes help boost your mood or manage anxiety. Would you like to come up with a small activity goal together for the week?
transcript.patient: I could try. Maybe just walk around the block once more each day.

transcript.clinician: That’s excellent. We’ll aim for that—no pressure if some days it doesn’t happen. Now, I wanted to check about thoughts of self-harm or feeling hopeless. Have you had any thoughts like that recently?
transcript.patient: No, not really. I get overwhelmed, but I haven’t wanted to hurt myself. Sometimes just wish things were easier or I could run away for a bit.

transcript.clinician: Those feelings are understandable when life is this hard. Remember you can always reach out here if you’re struggling. Do you feel able to keep yourself safe between now and our next session?
transcript.patient: Yes. I promised my sister and the kids. I know I can come in if things get bad.

transcript.clinician: That’s really good to hear, Alison. Are there things you do that make you feel even a little bit more hopeful, even briefly?
transcript.patient: Sometimes my kids say something funny, or draw a picture. That helps for a few minutes. Or if my sister makes me a cup of tea and we laugh about something silly on TV.

transcript.clinician: Those are really special moments, even if they’re small. Would you be willing to try and write down one of those moments each day, as a way to remind yourself there are good things even during a tough time?
transcript.patient: I guess I could try. Even little things?

transcript.clinician: Even the smallest things—even just noticing the kids laughing or something that made you smile.
transcript.patient: Okay. I’ll try to do that.

transcript.clinician: Alison, I also notice your screen time has gone up. Are you finding that using your phone is helping, or is it making things harder for you?
transcript.patient: Mostly just scrolling. It’s a distraction, but sometimes makes me feel worse—everyone seems so happy on there.

transcript.clinician: That can be tough. Maybe you can try limiting it, just for parts of the day, and replace a few minutes of scrolling with something else—like writing in your diary, or sending a message to a friend. How does that sound?
transcript.patient: Makes sense. I’ll try to put the phone down at night especially. Maybe that’ll help me sleep, too.

transcript.clinician: Definitely worth a try. Before we finish today, can we make a plan together for this week? Something like: 1) walk outside once, 2) write down one good thing each day, 3) message a friend, and 4) try writing in your diary. How does that feel?
transcript.patient: That sounds good, actually. Feels doable. I’ll try my best.

transcript.clinician: That’s all I ask, Alison—just try your best. We’ll check in on how it went next time, and see what helped. Is there anything else you want to talk about or ask before we end today?
transcript.patient: No, I think that’s it. Thanks for listening. It helps just saying it out loud.

transcript.clinician: You’re always welcome to share here, Alison. Remember, you’re not alone in this. I’ll see you next week—don’t hesitate to contact us sooner if you need support before then.
transcript.patient: Thanks. I’ll see you next week.

clinical_note:
**Subjective:**  
Alison returns for follow-up, reporting ongoing fatigue and low mood. She describes persistent sleep difficulties, with nights of minimal rest and frequent awakenings, despite attempts to increase physical activity. She continues to experience poor appetite, often skipping meals, and has noticed some unintentional weight loss (clothes fitting looser, family members commenting). Alison expresses feelings of guilt regarding her limited engagement with her children, who have become more self-sufficient. She reports a distant relationship with her partner, Dave, and finds it difficult to communicate her feelings, fearing she may be a burden. Alison acknowledges some support from her sister, which provides brief moments of relief, but overall she feels isolated and has withdrawn from friends. Work remains a significant stressor due to unstable hours and lack of support, contributing to her anxiety. She denies any current thoughts of self-harm or suicidality, stating she has made promises to her family and feels able to keep herself safe. Alison identifies small positive moments with her children and sister but finds it hard to sustain hope. She notes increased screen time, which serves as a distraction but sometimes worsens her mood. She is open to trying strategies such as journaling, reaching out to friends, and increasing outdoor activity.

**Objective:**  
- Appearance: Tired, low energy, affect congruent with mood.
- Speech: Normal rate and tone, coherent.
- Thought process: Logical, no evidence of psychosis.
- Mood: Depressed, anhedonic.
- Sleep: Ongoing insomnia, variable sleep duration, frequent awakenings.
- Appetite: Poor, decreased intake, unintentional weight loss.
- Medication adherence: Taking Sertraline daily as prescribed, no missed doses, no reported side effects.
- Social: Limited support network (sister supportive, children self-sufficient), minimal contact with friends, strained relationship with partner.
- Safety: Denies suicidal ideation or self-harm; safety plan in place.
- Function: Struggling with work attendance and performance due to anxiety and fatigue; minimal engagement in pleasurable activities.

**Assessment:**  
Alison continues to experience symptoms of moderate to severe major depressive disorder, with persistent low mood, anhedonia, insomnia, poor appetite, and social withdrawal. She is adherent to Sertraline with no side effects but has not noted significant improvement in core symptoms. Psychosocial stressors remain prominent, including work instability, limited social support, and strained family relationships. Protective factors include her commitment to her children and sister, willingness to engage in therapy, and openness to behavioral interventions. No acute safety concerns at present.

**Plan:**  
1. **Medication:** Continue Sertraline (50mg once daily in the morning). Monitor for efficacy and side effects. Consider dose adjustment or augmentation if no improvement at next review.
2. **Therapeutic Interventions:**  
   - Encourage daily journaling to process emotions and track positive moments.
   - Support Alison in initiating brief, honest conversations with her partner about her struggles, possibly starting with written communication.
   - Reinforce the value of small, achievable goals: walking outside at least once this week, messaging a friend, and writing down one positive moment each day.
   - Discuss strategies to limit screen time, especially before bed, to improve sleep hygiene.
3. **Social Support:**  
   - Encourage continued contact with her sister and gradual reconnection with friends (e.g., sending a text).
   - Explore additional community or peer support resources if isolation persists.
4. **Work/Function:**  
   - Validate work-related stress; discuss coping strategies for managing anxiety at work (e.g., brief breaks, breathing exercises).
   - Monitor impact of work instability on mood and functioning.
5. **Safety:**  
   - Reassess risk at each visit; Alison is aware of how to access crisis support if needed.
   - Maintain open communication regarding any changes in mood or safety.
6. **Follow-up:**  
   - Review progress on behavioral goals and symptom changes at next appointment (scheduled in one week).
   - Consider referral for additional psychological support (CBT or counseling) if symptoms persist or worsen.

Alison is receptive to the plan and agrees to try the outlined strategies. She will contact the clinic if her mood deteriorates or if she experiences any safety concerns before the next scheduled visit.

data_insights: Routine regularity and sleep fragmentation both worsen during periods of high stress and negative affect.
Periods of increased screen unlock duration align with higher PSS-4 and negative affect scores.
Sedentary behavior increases as positive affect scores remain low and negative affect rises.
Periods of increased digital engagement do not correspond with improved positive affect.
Sleep fragmentation and short duration coincide with rising negative affect and PHQ-4 scores in May.
Minimal time in green or exercise spaces persists despite fluctuating mood and stress scores.
Routine regularity drops during periods of high negative affect and PHQ-4 scores.
Outgoing and incoming call counts decline as PHQ-4 and negative affect scores rise.
High screen unlock frequency at home coincides with increased stress and negative affect.
Periods of increased mobility do not correspond with improved mood or affect scores.
Maximum screen unlock duration spikes during high stress and negative affect periods.
No time in study or exercise places, even as stress and negative affect increase.
Time at home remains high, with little change during periods of mood fluctuation.
Sleep onset and wake times are highly variable, paralleling emotional instability.
Reduced physical activity and increased sedentary episodes parallel rising PHQ-4 and PSS-4 scores.
Maximum number of significant places visited remains low, even during mood fluctuations.
Screen unlock duration at home is highly variable, with no clear link to positive affect.
Bluetooth and WiFi device counts remain low, consistent with limited social interaction and high home time.
Missed call counts remain low, consistent with limited social engagement and high home time.
PHQ-4 anxiety scores remain higher than depression, even as both increase with stress.

transcript.clinician: Hello Alison, welcome back. Thank you for coming in today. How have you been feeling since our last session?
transcript.patient: Hi. I suppose… about the same, honestly. Some days blur together. I did try some of the things we talked about, though.

transcript.clinician: I’m glad you gave those things a try. Can you tell me a bit about which ones you were able to do, and how they felt?
transcript.patient: I wrote down one good thing most days—like when the kids made me laugh, or my sister brought round some dinner. I managed to walk outside twice, just after dropping the kids off at school.

transcript.clinician: That’s a real achievement, especially given how hard things have felt. How was getting out for a walk?
transcript.patient: It was okay. First time I just kind of wanted to get back home, but the second time I went past the corner shop and saw an old neighbor. We just nodded and that was it—but it felt sort of normal for a minute.

transcript.clinician: Those little moments of connection can be meaningful. How did you feel after each walk?
transcript.patient: I guess it was better than just sitting at home. Didn't notice a huge change, but didn’t feel worse either. Just… different.

transcript.clinician: That’s good feedback. Sometimes the benefit is subtle, just getting a little distance from the cycle of thoughts at home. What about messaging a friend or writing in your diary—were you able to try those?
transcript.patient: I messaged my old workmate, like you suggested. She replied—it was just small talk but nice. I did write in the diary once or twice, mostly late at night when I couldn’t sleep.

transcript.clinician: That’s a great start. Even little steps like these can help rebuild a sense of connection and express your thoughts. How did you feel after writing or messaging?
transcript.patient: A bit lighter, I think. Less crowded in my head. Messaging… made me a bit anxious, like maybe she could tell I’m not really okay. But it was good to just talk about something else, even just about her cat.

transcript.clinician: It’s totally normal to feel anxious about reaching out, but that connection, as small as it is, really matters. How was your sleep and appetite this week? Any changes at all?
transcript.patient: Sleep is about the same. Some nights I’m scrolling on my phone too long, even though I tried to cut it back. I think I slept through two nights but then the next it was all over the place again.

transcript.clinician: That’s understandable—habits don’t change overnight. Did putting the phone down earlier make any difference when you tried?
transcript.patient: A bit. One night I put it away and read an old magazine. Still took ages to fall asleep but my mind wandered less. Maybe I’ll try it again.

transcript.clinician: Sounds promising. Sometimes these little habits build up to bigger changes. What about eating—are you still struggling with your appetite?
transcript.patient: Yeah, pretty much. Still skipping meals, just don’t feel hungry. The kids cooked scrambled eggs last night and I had a few bites, but mostly still just picking at things.

transcript.clinician: Thank you for sharing that. Low appetite is common with depression. How have your energy levels been—any improvement, or still quite low?
transcript.patient: Still really tired. Sometimes I have bursts—I’ll clean the kitchen or fold some laundry—but it goes almost as soon as it comes.

transcript.clinician: It’s exhausting carrying all this. I noticed in your data that screen time goes up when stress and low mood increase. Have you noticed that using your phone more makes you feel better or worse overall?
transcript.patient: Honestly, it’s a habit. I scroll through photos, through social media, even when it makes me feel worse. Feels like something to do when the house is quiet.

transcript.clinician: You’re not alone—many people do that. But being aware of it is the first step. When you’ve put the phone away, have you found anything else helpful to wind down in the evenings?
transcript.patient: Maybe the diary a little. If I’m really exhausted, I just try to close my eyes and listen to music or a podcast for a bit.

transcript.clinician: That’s a great strategy—music and podcasts can be grounding and soothing. Would you like to try doing that a bit more this coming week to see if it helps you relax?
transcript.patient: Sure, I can try. I’ll play some of my old playlists. Used to listen a lot before all this.

transcript.clinician: That’s a good plan, Alison. Let’s move on to your relationships a bit. Have you had any more conversations with Dave about how you’re feeling, or any changes in that area?
transcript.patient: Not really. I thought about what we talked about last time, but I sort of chickened out. He’s been quiet too. Sent a few texts but doesn’t come by much lately.

transcript.clinician: That sounds really difficult. Does his distance make you feel more alone, or is it a relief in some way?
transcript.patient: A bit of both. I miss when things felt easy between us. But sometimes it’s easier not to have to pretend I’m okay.

transcript.clinician: It can be such a weight, feeling like you need to put on an act. Would you be open to practicing what you could say to him—with me first, just to take the pressure off?
transcript.patient: Maybe. I just don’t want him to think I’m pushing him away on purpose.

transcript.clinician: That’s understandable. Even telling him it’s hard to talk because you care and don’t want to be a burden might help him understand better. Want to try saying just that much here first?
transcript.patient: Okay. Um… 'Sorry I’ve been distant. It’s nothing you’ve done, I just feel really low and it’s hard to talk about it. I don’t want to make you worry or feel like I’m pushing you away.'

transcript.clinician: That’s very heartfelt and honest, Alison. How did it feel saying those words out loud?
transcript.patient: Weird, but kind of a relief, even if it’s just to you.

transcript.clinician: Sometimes practicing helps lower the fear a bit. Would you feel comfortable trying to share just a little bit of that with Dave during the week? Maybe even in a message if face-to-face feels too much?
transcript.patient: Maybe a message…I might not be able to say it out loud. I’ll try.

transcript.clinician: That’s all I ask. Do it at your pace. Now, about your sister—you mentioned she’s still supportive. How often have you seen or talked with her this week?
transcript.patient: She came round twice, brought some stew over. We watched some TV together. We talk on the phone most nights, even if just for a few minutes.

transcript.clinician: That connection is really valuable, even when you don’t talk about anything deep. How does it make you feel after spending time with her?
transcript.patient: Usually a little lighter. She jokes around a lot, tries to make me laugh. Sometimes I cry after she leaves, but it’s not a bad cry.

transcript.clinician: Letting yourself feel emotions is healthy, not something to be ashamed of. You’re doing a lot, managing work, kids, and your own mental health. How has work been this past week?
transcript.patient: The supermarket is still chaos. More people had their hours cut. I ended up missing a shift because I just couldn’t get out of bed. I called in sick, but now I feel guilty.

transcript.clinician: That situation sounds very stressful. Did anyone at work check in or ask how you’re doing?
transcript.patient: A couple of the ladies texted, just to say sorry about the shifts. The manager just noted it down, didn’t really ask.

transcript.clinician: It's tough, facing that sort of environment. Do you think talking to your colleagues about how you’re feeling would be helpful or more stressful?
transcript.patient: Maybe just the one I texted before. She’s always been nice. The rest, not really.

transcript.clinician: Would it feel safe to let her know you’re struggling, just so someone at work understands?
transcript.patient: Maybe. I don’t want anyone thinking I can’t do my job, though. But I might say I’m having a hard time at home.

transcript.clinician: That sounds like a good middle ground. Even letting her know you’re going through a tough patch could help. How about the kids—has anything changed with them this week?
transcript.patient: My daughter asked again if I was okay. She drew me a picture and left it on my pillow. My son was quiet, but he hugged me when I looked upset. Guilt is still there.

transcript.clinician: You’re still giving your kids love, even if it doesn’t feel like enough. Children often sense more than we know, and the fact that your daughter made something for you shows she cares deeply. Did their gestures lift your mood, even for a moment?
transcript.patient: Yes. It feels like I’m not totally failing—even if it only helps for a minute.

transcript.clinician: You’re not failing them, Alison. Those small moments are evidence of the love between you. Have you had any thoughts about self-harm or hopelessness since we last spoke?
transcript.patient: No, not really. I get overwhelmed and wish everything would stop spinning for a while, but haven’t wanted to hurt myself.

transcript.clinician: Thank you for being honest. If things change, do you feel able to talk to your sister or to me, or come in for extra support?
transcript.patient: I think so. My sister keeps saying I should call if I ever feel really bad again, day or night. I promised her I would.

transcript.clinician: That’s reassuring. You have a plan and people to turn to. Let’s think about goals for the next week. Would you be comfortable continuing to write down one good thing each day, try a walk at least once, message either a friend or Dave, and use music or a podcast in the evening?
transcript.patient: Yes, I can try all those. I’ll try to write in the diary too, maybe more than once.

transcript.clinician: That sounds excellent. No pressure if you miss a day—just small steps. Would it be helpful to set a reminder on your phone, or perhaps your daughter could help remind you to write down the good things?
transcript.patient: Maybe a reminder on my phone. I don’t want the kids to worry more.

transcript.clinician: Good idea, respecting their boundaries. Before we wrap up, is there anything else on your mind—any worries or questions we haven’t covered?
transcript.patient: Just worried about money, if the hours get cut again. And what if this is as good as it gets?

transcript.clinician: Those are real worries. You don’t have to face them alone—we can discuss practical support next time, like community services or financial advice, if that might help. And depression isn’t forever, Alison. You’re taking steps, and things can improve with support.
transcript.patient: That gives me some hope, I suppose. It helps to talk, even if it’s just like this.

transcript.clinician: I’m glad to hear that. Let’s make a plan to meet again next week—same time? And remember, you can reach out before then if anything feels too much.
transcript.patient: Okay. Same time works. Thanks, really.

transcript.clinician: Always here for you, Alison. Take care until next week—you’re stronger than you think.
transcript.patient: Thank you. I’ll see you next week.

clinical_note:
**Subjective:**  
Alison returns for follow-up, reporting that her mood has remained largely unchanged since the last session, with days often blending together. She describes ongoing low energy, persistent fatigue, and continued difficulty with motivation. Alison has made efforts to implement some behavioral strategies discussed previously: she wrote down one positive thing most days, walked outside twice, messaged an old workmate, and wrote in her diary on a couple of occasions. She notes that these activities provided brief moments of relief or normalcy, though the overall impact was subtle. Messaging a friend made her feel both lighter and somewhat anxious. Sleep remains inconsistent; she sometimes scrolls on her phone late at night despite attempts to reduce screen time, but found that reading a magazine instead helped her mind wander less. Appetite is still poor, with frequent skipped meals and only occasional small portions eaten, often when prompted by her children. Alison continues to feel guilty about her perceived lack of engagement with her children and work, having missed a shift due to low motivation. She describes her relationship with her partner, Dave, as distant, and feels both lonely and somewhat relieved by his absence. She has not had thoughts of self-harm or active hopelessness, though she does feel overwhelmed at times. Alison identifies her sister as a key support, with regular visits and phone calls providing some comfort. She expresses ongoing worries about finances and the possibility that her current state may not improve.

**Objective:**  
- Affect: Flat to mildly reactive; able to express some positive emotions when discussing children and sister.
- Speech: Normal rate and tone, coherent.
- Thought process: Logical, though content reflects low mood and self-criticism.
- Sleep: Fragmented, with some improvement when reducing screen time.
- Appetite: Decreased, with minimal intake.
- Energy: Low, with occasional brief bursts of activity.
- Social: Maintains some contact with family and friends; limited engagement at work.
- No evidence of psychosis, mania, or active suicidal ideation.
- Taking sertraline as previously prescribed.

**Assessment:**  
Alison continues to experience symptoms consistent with moderate major depressive disorder, including persistent low mood, anhedonia, low energy, poor sleep, reduced appetite, and feelings of guilt and worthlessness. She is making incremental progress with behavioral activation strategies, such as journaling, walking, and reaching out to others, though the benefits are subtle and not yet sustained. Protective factors include strong support from her sister and children, willingness to engage in therapy, and absence of suicidal ideation. Stressors include financial insecurity, reduced work hours, and relationship difficulties with her partner. No current pharmacological intervention.

**Plan:**  
- Continue weekly psychotherapy sessions focused on behavioral activation, cognitive restructuring, and social support.
- Encourage Alison to maintain daily journaling of positive experiences, aim for at least one walk per week, and use music or podcasts in the evening as a relaxation strategy.
- Support gradual communication with her partner, starting with written messages if face-to-face feels overwhelming.
- Reinforce the importance of reaching out to her sister or clinician if mood worsens or if thoughts of self-harm emerge.
- Discuss practical supports for financial stress and community resources at the next session.
- No medication needed at this time; continue to monitor for any changes in mood, sleep, appetite, or safety concerns.
- Next appointment scheduled for the same time next week. Alison is encouraged to reach out sooner if needed.

Outgoing call count peaked in June, but PHQ-4 depression scores remained elevated.
Time in green spaces increased after May 23, but positive affect scores did not improve.
Maximum screen unlock duration peaked late May, coinciding with highest PHQ-4 score.
Positive affect reached a minimum on May 19, while time at home was already dropping.
Total distance traveled peaked on May 21, but PHQ-4 scores remained high.
Average awake duration increased in late May, coinciding with higher negative affect scores.
Time in exercise spaces increased in June, but positive affect scores did not improve.
Time at home dropped to zero, while PHQ-4 depression scores and negative affect increased.
PHQ-4 depression and negative affect scores both peaked mid-May, with increased missed calls.
Unique WiFi and Bluetooth devices increased, but routine regularity dropped, suggesting more varied but less structured environments.
Number of screen unlock episodes at home dropped as time at home reached zero.
Routine regularity and time at home both became highly variable after May 10, with increased missed calls.
Sedentary episodes increased in early June, despite higher total steps and travel distance.
Routine regularity dropped sharply on May 22, coinciding with zero time at home and increased missed calls.
Total sleep duration increased in June, but number of sleep episodes also rose, suggesting fragmented sleep.
Number of sleep episodes increased, but average sleep duration remained low, indicating fragmented sleep.
